{{TopicTOC-World War II}} {{WWII timeline}} {{Sweden during World War II}} A number of '''internment camps''' were operated by [[Sweden]] [[Sweden in World War II|during World War II]]. These camps were used for [[internment]] of, among others, suspected criminals, German refugees, anarchists and Swedish [[communist]]s. Military personnel from both sides in the war, if they entered Sweden without prior agreement, were also often subject to internment. The camps were claimed to have been a decision necessary in the ambition to keep Sweden out of the war. It was made by the then-ruling [[Third cabinet of Per Albin Hansson|grand coalition government]] under social democrat prime minister [[Per Albin Hansson]], which all included all parties in the [[Parliament of Sweden]], with the notable exception of the [[Left Party (Sweden)|Communist Party of Sweden]]. ==Camps during the war== [[File:Internering-Sveg.jpg|thumb|An internment camp in 1940]] In February 1940, the decision was made to build several internment camps, which are believed to have held around 3,000 inmates between the years 1940-1948.Berglund, Tobias . Interview. "45." En bok - en författare. SVT. 26 Jan. 2009 <{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/svt/road/Classic/shared/mediacenter/index.jsp?d%3D37875%26a%3D1291295%3E. |accessdate=January 29, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl= |archivedate=January 1, 1970 }} - [[Axmarby|Axmar]], [[Gävle Municipality]], [[Gävleborg County]] (1945) - Ede, [[Krokom Municipality]], [[Jämtland County]] (1943–1948) - Florsberg, [[Söderhamn Municipality]], [[Gävleborg County]] (1943–1948) - Grytan, [[Östersund Municipality]], [[Jämtland County]] (January–September 1942) - Hälsingmo, [[Söderhamn Municipality]], [[Gävleborg County]] (1943–1948) - Ingels, [[Rättvik Municipality]], [[Dalarna County]] (1942–1946) - Kusfors, [[Norsjö Municipality]], [[Västerbotten County]] (1944–1945) - Långmora, [[Hedemora Municipality]], [[Dalarna County]] (March 1940-1945) - Lövnäsvallen, [[Härjedalen Municipality]], [[Jämtland County]] (September 1941–January 1942) - Naartijärvi, [[Haparanda Municipality]], [[Norrbotten County]] (January–March 1940) - Norra Bredåker, [[Boden Municipality]], [[Norrbotten County]] (December 1939–January 1940) (Merged with [[Storsien]] internment camp in January 1940) - [[Rengsjö]], [[Bollnäs Municipality]], [[Gävleborg County]] (1942–1945) - Smedsbo, [[Falun Municipality]], [[Dalarna County]] (March 1940-1945) - [[Stensele]], [[Storuman Municipality]], [[Västerbotten County]] (August–October 1943) - [[Storsien]], [[Kalix Municipality]], [[Norrbotten County]] (December 1939–April 1940; May–July 1940) - Sunnerstaholm, [[Bollnäs Municipality]], [[Gävleborg County]] (1945–1946) - [[Säter]], [[Säter Municipality]], [[Dalarna County]] (1943–1946) - Sörbyn, [[Boden Municipality]], [[Norrbotten County]] (1944–1945) - [[Tjörnarp]], [[Höör Municipality]], [[Skåne County]] (1945–1946) - [[Vindeln]], [[Vindeln Municipality]], [[Västerbotten County]] (August–October 1943) - Vägershult, [[Uppvidinge Municipality]], [[Kronoberg County]] (1942–1945) - [[Öxnered]], [[Vänersborg Municipality]], [[Västra Götaland County]] (September 1941–January 1942){{cite book |last=Berglund |first=Tobias |last2=Sennerteg |first2=Niclas |title=Svenska koncentrationsläger i Tredje rikets skugga |trans-title=Swedish Concentration Camps in the Shadow of the Third Reich |year=2008 |publisher=[[Natur & Kultur]] |location=Stockholm |language=sv |isbn=9789127026957 |id={{LIBRIS|10654055}} |pages=12-14}}{{cite web|last1=Andersson|first1=Felix|title=Arbetskompani L 17 Öxnered De svenska arbetskompanierna under andra världskriget|url=http://vanersborgssonersgille.se/onewebmedia/%C3%85rsskifter/2012/2012.pdf|accessdate=28 October 2017}} ===Internees=== [[Internee]]s were commonly suspected criminals, German refugees, left-wing activists or anti-Nazis. They were imprisoned without trial and without being informed of the accusations made against them. Most of these were foreigners.{{cite book |last=Berglund |first=Tobias |last2=Sennerteg |first2=Niclas |title=Svenska koncentrationsläger i Tredje rikets skugga |trans-title=Swedish Concentration Camps in the Shadow of the Third Reich |year=2008 |publisher=[[Natur & Kultur]] |location=Stockholm |language=sv |isbn=9789127026957 |id={{LIBRIS|10654055}} |page=54}}Berglund, Tobias . Interview. "45." En bok - en författare. SVT. 26 Jan. 2009 <{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/svt/road/Classic/shared/mediacenter/index.jsp?d%3D37875%26a%3D1291295%3E. |accessdate=January 29, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl= |archivedate=January 1, 1970 }} ===Treatment=== Wardens were instructed to ensure humane treatment of internees. All internees were forced to wear certain uniform and submit daily routines. Internees in Smedsbo internment camp had a typical daily routine of being woken up at 7.15am, they were then escorted to the dining room where they were expected to have their breakfast in complete silence followed by working passes. They were not permitted to leave their working station at any time. Jobs like road building, repair duty and woodcutting were commonly adopted. With one break for lunch, work proceeded until 2.45pm, after which internees were more or less free for the rest of the day.{{cite book |last=Berglund |first=Tobias |last2=Sennerteg |first2=Niclas |title=Svenska koncentrationsläger i Tredje rikets skugga |trans-title=Swedish Concentration Camps in the Shadow of the Third Reich |year=2008 |publisher=[[Natur & Kultur]] |location=Stockholm |language=sv |isbn=9789127026957 |id={{LIBRIS|10654055}} |pages=77-83}} ==Internment of Allied air crews== A number of [[Allies of World War II|Western Allied]] servicemen, primarily crew members of the aircraft damaged during bombing missions over Germany, found themselves on Swedish soil, and were interned by the Swedish authorities. Unlike civilian refugees from Germany, who were kept in internment camps, Allied airmen were placed in hotels and [[bed and breakfast]] establishments in the [[Falun]] area, and enjoyed relative freedom. They received their regular military pay from their home countries, which allowed them to be much better off than the local Swedish residents.Jöran Granberg, [Memories of the Framby Internment Camp in Falun Sweden, 1942-1944], 2008 ==“Disclosure”== In 2008, Swedish journalist Niclas Sennerteg and researcher Tobias Berglund published ''Swedish Concentration Camps in the Shadow of the Third Reich'' (Swedish title: “Svenska koncentrationsläger i tredje rikets skugga”), where they claim to be exposing what the government had kept secret regarding the presence of Swedish concentration camps. After the discovery was brought to media and thus public attention, the use of the term concentration camp has been highly debated. ==Post-war use of Swedish internment camps== After the war the internment camps were used to store foreigners that the [[Swedish government]] deemed dubious. However, details regarding much of this have still not been uncovered.{{cite book |last=Berglund |first=Tobias |last2=Sennerteg |first2=Niclas |title=Svenska koncentrationsläger i Tredje rikets skugga |trans-title=Swedish Concentration Camps in the Shadow of the Third Reich |year=2008 |publisher=[[Natur & Kultur]] |location=Stockholm |language=sv |isbn=9789127026957 |id={{LIBRIS|10654055}} |page=229}} ==Quotes==
"Den svenska staten använder sig av brutala tvångs- och våldsmetoder för att eftertryckligt trampa ned den utländska antifascisten som likt en vrakspillra efter den tyska demokratins skeppsbrott kastats upp på svensk strand" [[Arbetaren]], 21 mars 1940”.
''Translation:''
"The Swedish government is using brutal methods to forcefully crush the foreign antifascists who like remnants after the shipwreck of the German democracy was washed upon Swedish shores.”
"Det svenska folket får inte tolerera att oskyldiga människor kastas i fängelse och kvarhålles där på obestämd tid.”{{cite news |title=En skam för Sverige |newspaper=[[Ny Dag]] |date=15 December 1942 |language=sv}}
''Translation:''
”The Swedish people must not tolerate the imprisonment of innocent people for an undetermined time.”
==See also== * [[List of concentration and internment camps]] * [[Sweden in World War II]] ==Notes and references== {{reflist}} ==External links== * http://www.bt.se/nyheter/boras/bt-journalist-avslojar-svenska-koncentrationslager-i-ny-bok(823045).gm#comments {{DEFAULTSORT:Internment Camps In Sweden During World War Ii}} [[Category:Sweden in World War II]] [[Category:World War II internment camps]] [[Category:World War II sites in Sweden]] [[Category:Political repression]] [[Category:Anti-communism in Sweden]]

The '''Islamic Legion''' ([[Arabic]]: الفيلق الإسلامي ''al-Faylaq ul-'Islāmiyyu''<ref name=prunier45>G. Prunier, ''Darfur: The Ambiguous Genocide'', p. 45</ref>) ({{aka}} Islamic Pan-African Legion) was a [[Libya]]n-sponsored [[Pan-Arabism|pan-Arabist]] [[paramilitary]] force, created in 1972. The Legion was part of [[Muammar Gaddafi]]'s dream of creating the Great Islamic State of the [[Sahel]].<ref>S. Nolutshungu, ''Limits of Anarchy'', p. 127</ref>
==Creation== Gaddafi, who had come to power in September 1969, was not only a [[Pan-Africanism|Pan-Africanist]], but an [[Arabs|Arab]] cultural [[supremacism|supremacist]].<ref>Prunier, Gérard, Darfur: The Ambiguous Genocide, Cornell University Press, 2005, {{ISBN|0-8014-4450-0}}</ref> His hostility to [[Chad]]'s government of [[President of Chad|President]] [[François Tombalbaye]] was at least partly inspired by Tombalbaye's [[Ethnic groups of Africa|African]] and [[Christianity|Christian]] background. It also led Gaddafi to drive the [[Toubou]] of Libya, who were considered 'black', from [[Fezzan]] and across the Chadian border. Gaddafi supported the [[Sudan]]ese government of [[Gaafar Nimeiry]], referring to it as an "Arab Nationalist Revolutionary Movement", and even offered to merge the two countries at a meeting in late 1971. Gaddafi's plans for the peaceful formation of an "[[Arab Union]]" were dashed when Nimeiry turned down his offer and negotiated the [[Addis Ababa Agreement (1972)|Addis Ababa Agreement]] ending the [[First Sudanese Civil War]], fought with the Black, [[Animism|animist]] and Christian, [[South Sudan|South]].<ref>Prunier, pp. 43-45</ref> Gaddafi's definition of "Arab" was broad, including the [[Tuareg people|Tuareg]] of [[Mali]] and [[Niger]], as well as the [[Zaghawa people|Zaghawa]] of Chad and Sudan.<ref>Flint and de Waal, ''Darfur: A Short History of a Long War'', p. 23</ref>
In 1972, Gaddafi created the Islamic Legion as a tool to unify and Arabize the region. The priority of the Legion was first Chad, and then Sudan. In [[Darfur]], a western province of Sudan, Gaddafi supported the creation of the Arab Gathering (Tajammu al-Arabi), which according to Gérard Prunier was "a militantly racist and pan-Arabist organization which stressed the 'Arab' character of the province."<ref name=prunier45/> The two organizations shared members and a source of support, and the distinction between the two is often ambiguous.
==The Legion== This Islamic Legion was mostly composed of immigrants from poorer [[Sahel]]ian countries,<ref name=Nolutshungu220>S. Nolutshungu, p. 220</ref> but also, according to a source, thousands of [[Pakistan]]is and some [[Bangladesh]]is who had been recruited since 1981 with the false promise of civilian jobs once in Libya.<ref>J. Thomson, ''Mercenaries, Pirates and Sovereigns'', p. 91</ref> Generally speaking, the Legion's members were immigrants who had gone to Libya with no thought of fighting wars, and had been provided with inadequate military training and had sparse commitment. A French journalist{{who|date=December 2012}}, speaking of the Legion's forces in Chad, observed that they were "foreigners, Arabs or Africans, [[mercenary|mercenaries]] in spite of themselves, wretches who had come to Libya hoping for a civilian job, but found themselves signed up more or less by force to go and fight in an unknown desert."<ref name=Nolutshungu220/>
According to the Military Balance published by the [[International Institute for Strategic Studies]], the force was organized into one armored, one infantry, and one paratroop/commando brigade. It had been supplied with [[T-54]] and T-55 tanks, armored personnel carriers, and [[EE-9]] armored cars. The Legion was reported to have been committed during the fighting in Chad in 1980 and was praised by Gaddafi for its success there. However, it was believed that many of the troops who fled the Chadian attacks of March 1987 were members of the Legion.
Gaddafi dispatched legionnaires to [[Uganda]], [[State of Palestine|Palestine]], [[Lebanon]] and [[Syria]],<ref>J.-P. Azam et al., ''Conflict and Growth in Africa'', p. 168</ref> but the Legion was to be mostly associated with the [[Chadian–Libyan conflict]], where already in 1980 7,000 legionnaires participated to the second battle of N'Djamena,<ref>G. Simons, ''Libya and the West'', p. 57</ref> where its fighting record was most noted for its ineptitude.<ref>J. Wright, ''Libya'', p. 140</ref> To this force [[Benin]]'s [[Marxism|Marxist]] regime is said to have provided legionnaires during the 1983 offensive in Chad.<ref>J. Markakis & M. Waller, ''Military Marxist Regimes'', p. 73</ref> At the beginning of the 1987 Libyan offensive into Chad, it maintained a force of 2,000 in Darfur. The nearly continuous cross-border raids that resulted greatly contributed to a separate ethnic conflict within Darfur that killed about 9,000 people between 1985 and 1988.<ref>Prunier, pp. 61-65</ref>
The Legion was disbanded by Gaddafi following its defeats in Chad in 1987 and the Libyan retreat from that country. But its consequences in this region can still be felt. Some of the [[Janjaweed]] leaders were among those said to have been trained in Libya,<ref>{{cite journal| last =de Waal| first =Alex| title =Counter-Insurgency on the Cheap| journal = [[London Review of Books]]| volume =26| issue =15| date =2004-08-05| url =http://www.lrb.co.uk/v26/n15/waal01_.html}}</ref> as many [[Darfur]]i followers of the [[Umma Party (Sudan)|Umma Party]] were forced in exile in the 1970s and 1980s.<ref>{{cite journal|last=McGregor |first=Andrew |title=Terrorism and Violence in the Sudan: The Islamist Manipulation of Darfur |journal=Terrorism Monitor |volume=3 |issue=12 |date=2005-06-17 |publisher=[[The Jamestown Foundation]] |url=http://www.jamestown.org/terrorism/news/article.php?articleid=2369723 |format=– <sup>[https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=author%3AMcGregor+intitle%3ATerrorism+and+Violence+in+the+Sudan%3A+The+Islamist+Manipulation+of+Darfur&as_publication=Terrorism+Monitor&as_ylo=&as_yhi=&btnG=Search Scholar search]</sup> |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061016211725/http://jamestown.org/terrorism/news/article.php?articleid=2369723 |archivedate=October 16, 2006 }}</ref>
The Legion was also to leave a strong impact on the [[Tuareg people|Tuareg]] living in [[Mali]] and [[Niger]]. A series of severe [[drought]]s had brought many young Tuareg to migrate to Libya, where a number of them were recruited into the Legion, receiving an indoctrination that told them to reject their hereditary chiefs and to fight those governments that excluded the Tuareg from power. After the disbandment of the Legion, these men were to return to their countries and to play an important role in the Tuareg rebellions that erupted in the two countries in 1989–90.<ref>J.-P. Azam et al., p. 14</ref>
Immediately prior to the overthrow of the Gaddafi regime, there were media reports that his hard-core of supporters included former members of the Islamic Legion who had been granted Libyan citizenship and remained in the country.<ref>Washington Post, March 11, 2011</ref>
==Afterwards== In an effort to realize Gaddafi's vision of a united Arab military force, plans for the creation of an Arab Legion have been announced from time to time. The goal, according to the Libyan press, would be to assemble an army of 1 million men and women fighters to prepare for the great Arab battle--"the battle of liberating Palestine, of toppling the reactionary regimes, of annihilating the borders, gates, and barriers between the countries of the Arab homeland, and of creating the single Arab Jamahiriya from the ocean to the gulf." In March 1985, it was announced that the National Command of the Revolutionary Forces Command in the Arab Nation had been formed with Gaddafi at its head. A number of smaller radical Arab groups from Lebanon, Tunisia, Sudan, Iraq, the Persian Gulf states, and Jordan were represented at the inaugural meeting. Syrian Baath Party and radical Palestinian factions were also present. Each of these movements was expected to earmark 10 percent of its forces for service under the new command. As of April 1987, there was no information confirming the existence of such a militia.

{{Infobox political party |name = Jewish Social Democratic Party |native_name = Yidishe sotsial-demokratishe partey |founded = 1905 |split = [[Polish Social Democratic Party of Galicia]] |ideology = [[Social democracy]] |position = [[Left wing]] }}
The '''Jewish Social Democratic Party''' (in [[Yiddish]], ''Yidishe sotsial-demokratishe partey'', {{lang-pl|Żydowska Partia Socjal-Demokratyczna}}, abbreviated '''ŻPS''') was a [[political party]] in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]] and later also [[Bukovina]], established in a split from the [[Polish Social Democratic Party of Galicia]] (PPSD) in 1905. The party made its first public appearance on May 1, 1905, with separate [[May Day]] rallies in [[Kraków]], [[Lemberg]], [[Tarnów]] and [[Przemyśl]]. However, as the new party stressed that it was not a competitor of the existing Social Democratic parties, they later joined the PPSD celebrations.<ref name="anu">Kuhn, Rick [http://auspsa.anu.edu.au/proceedings/2002/kuhn.pdf 'The tradition of Jewish anti-Zionism in the Galician socialist movement' <!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080720045128/http://auspsa.anu.edu.au/proceedings/2002/kuhn.pdf |date=2008-07-20 }} Resistance and class stream, Australasian Political Studies Association APSA50 Conference, Canberra, 2–4 October 2002</ref>
The Party, often nicknamed the 'Galician Bund', was influenced by the [[General Jewish Labour Bund in Lithuania, Poland and Russia|Bund]] in Russia and was opposed to Zionism.<ref name="brenner"/>
ŻPS held its founding congress in June 1905.<ref name="anu"/> The second congress was held in 1906.<ref name="brenner">Brenner, Michael/Penslar, Derek Jonathan. ''In search of Jewish community : Jewish identities in Germany and Austria, 1918-1933''. [[Bloomington, Indiana|Bloomington]]: Indiana University press, c1998. p. 118</ref>
Its founding theoretician and secretary was [[Henryk Grossman]]. While the Party sought affiliation to the [[SPÖ|Social Democratic Workers Party of Austria]], this was refused. The ŻPS became the largest organisation of Jewish workers in Galicia.<ref name="Kuhn">Kuhn, Rick ''Henryk Grossman and the Recovery of Marxism'' Urbana and Chicago: University of Illinois Press, 2007. {{ISBN|0-252-07352-5}}.</ref>
In the initial period of the existence of the party, it publish a monthtly titled ''Der yudisher sotsial-demokrat''. In October 1905 it was replaced by a weekly, ''Der sotsial-demokrat''. As of 1910, ''Der sotsial-demokrat'' had a circulation of 2000.<ref name="j2">Jacobs, Jack Lester. ''Jewish Politics in Eastern Europe: The Bund at 100''. Basingstoke: Palgrave, 2001. pp. 141-143</ref>
In 1911 the Jewish Social Democracy in Galicia, the Jewish affiliate section of the PPSD, merged into the ŻPS.<ref name="brenner"/> The Jewish Social Democracy in Galicia had 377 members at the time of the merger.<ref name="j2"/> The strength of the party reached its peak when the [[Bund (Bukovina)|Bukovina Bundists]] merged into the party the following year. The united party took the name '''Jewish Social Democratic Party in Galicia and Bukovina'''.<ref name="brenner"/><ref>http://www.jewishgen.org/yizkor/Bukowinabook/buk1_127.html</ref>
In 1913, several prominent leaders of the erstwhile Jewish Social Democracy began returning to the PPSD. More devastating for the ŻPS, though, was the outbreak of the [[First World War]]. Galicia and Bukovina became battlefield, and party activities ceased. The branch in [[Cracow]] was reconstructed in 1916, and in the fall of 1917 there was a conference of delegates from different local ŻPS branches. On 15, 1918 ''Der sotsial-demokrat'' reappeared.<ref>Jacobs, Jack Lester. ''Jewish Politics in Eastern Europe: The Bund at 100''. Basingstoke: Palgrave, 2001. p. 145</ref>
In 1920, its organisation in Poland merged with the [[Polish Bund]].<ref name="Kuhn"/><ref>Marcus, Joseph. ''Social and political history of the Jews in Poland, 1919-1939''. [[Berlin]]/[[New York City]]: Mouton Publishers, 1983. p. 280-281</ref><ref>Kisman, Yusf 'Di yidishe sotsial-demokratishe bevegung in Galitsie un Bukovine', in G. Aronson, S. Dubnov-Erlikh, J. S. Herts, and others (eds) ''Di Geshikhte fun Bund drite band'', New York: Farlag Unser Tsait, pp. 337-480</ref> In Bukovina, now part of [[Romania]], the remnants of the party continued to operate under the name 'Bund', and in 1922 they founded (along with Jewish socialists from Old Romania and [[Bessarabia]]) the [[General Jewish Labour Bund in Romania]].<ref>http://www.jewishgen.org/yizkor/Bukowinabook/buk1_129.html</ref>
==Membership== The party had 2800 members in 1906, by 1908 the figure had risen to 3600 and by 1910 it claimed a membership of 4206.<ref name="brenner"/> At the time, the party had 80 branches in 32 different localities.<ref name="j2"/> In 1911, after the merger with the Bukovina Bund, the party had 4500 members.<ref name="j3">Jacobs, Jack Lester. ''Jewish Politics in Eastern Europe: The Bund at 100''. Basingstoke: Palgrave, 2001. p. 144</ref>
Except for its organization in Galicia and Bukovina, the party also had presence (at warying times) in [[Vienna]], [[New York City]], [[Antwerp]] and [[Bielsk, Masovian Voivodeship|Bielsk]].<ref name="j3"/>

{{for|the Finnish painter|Johan Backman (painter)}} {{Infobox person |name = Johan Bäckman |box_width = |image = Johan_Backman_Nashi_Demonstration_Helsinki_2009.jpg |image_width = |caption = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1971|05|18|df=yes}} |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |residence = |citizenship = |nationality = [[Finland|Finnish]] |ethnicity = |field = |work_institutions = |alma_mater = [[University of Helsinki]] |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = controversial views, pro-Russian statements, criticism of the Estonian government |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |prizes = |religion = |footnotes = |signature = }} '''Erkki Johan Bäckman''' (born 18 May 1971) is a [[Finland|Finnish]] political activist, author and [[legal sociologist]]. In Russia he is also considered a [[human rights activist]]. He has been active in relation to Russian citizens' child custody rights abroad, and is regularly interviewed by the Russian media as a child custody expert. Bäckman has contentious views about Estonia, Latvia and Ukraine, and has been declared [[persona non grata]] and denied entry into Estonia, and has been expelled from Moldova. Bäckman's books have been the subject of intense debate about [[Finnish-Soviet Relations|Finnish-Soviet relations]] during the [[Cold War]], the war history of Finland and the Soviet Union, [[organized crime]] in [[Estonia]] and the [[Russian Mafia]], terrorism, and the [[history of Estonia]]. As a spokesman for the [[Finnish Anti-Fascist Committee]] he is against the [[Social integration|integration policies]] of [[Estonia]] and [[Latvia]], claiming they are "[[Crime of apartheid|apartheid]] policies". On the whole, he does not recognize them as states. Bäckman supported Russia during the [[Ukrainian crisis]], and also claims to represent the separatist [[Donetsk People's Republic]] in Finland.{{cite web | title = SDP politician’s support of East-Ukrainian separatists raises eyebrows | url = http://yle.fi/uutiset/sdp_politicians_support_of_east-ukrainian_separatists_raises_eyebrows/7377804 | publisher = [[Yle]] | date = 26 July 2014 | accessdate=11 August 2014 }} Bäckman has a title of a [[docent]] in [[sociology of law]] and in criminology, and has previously taught courses on the sociology of law, criminology, and Russian studies in several Finnish universities. He has a background in music and became a public figure in the late 1980s then participating in EBU Young Soloists Competition. == Bäckman and Russia == Bäckman is highly critical of the modern Finnish historiography of [[World War II]] and challenges the traditional Western account that Finland waged a separate [[Continuation War]] against the aggression of the USSR. According to Bäckman, the Finns participated in the [[Siege of Leningrad]] actively and asked [[Adolf Hitler|Hitler]] to destroy the city. He speculates that Finland also planned an [[ethnic cleansing]] in [[Karelia]] in order to create a [[Finno-Ugric peoples|Finno-Ugric]] [[superpower]], possibly stretching as far as [[the Urals]], or even to the river [[Yenisei]], which he claimed is proven by vast amounts of documents and in several Finnish history books by [[Helge Seppälä]], [[Osmo Hyytiä]] and Nikolai Baryshnikov. Bäckman accuses Finland of being the aggressor in World War II: that it allied with Hitler in attacking the USSR in 1941 ([[Continuation War]])—omitting the original source conflict ([[Winter War]]); plotted territorial expansion and planned to conduct ethnic cleansing; and that, along with the Estonians and Germans, believed in its Aryan origins (a Nordic master race). He contends Finns are both anti-Semitic and Russophobic, Russophobia being a "racist political ideology"—both per "several academic works by Finnish authors."Bäckman, J. "The Janša-Patria Case (or Chase): A Challenge for Mediacriminology"—Primer Janša-Patria (lov na čarovnice): izziv za kriminologijo medijev In 2002, Bäckman publicly accused the [[Foreign Ministry of Finland]] of [[Russophobia]] and racism. He claimed that the ministry was preparing a campaign to smear Russia and return the territories lost in the [[Paris Peace Treaty]].{{ru icon}} [http://www.gov.karelia.ru/Karelia/990/39.html йЮПЕКХЪ N 4 (16 ЪМБЮПЪ 2003): опнькне - мюярнъыее: вЕЛС МЮЯ СВХР ЦНПЭЙХИ НОШР...пЮГЦНБНПШ НА ЮЙРХБХГЮЖХХ ЮМРХПСЯЯЙХУ МЮЯРПНЕМХИ Б тХМКЪМДХХ, ЯЙНПЕЕ БЯЕЦН, ОПЕЯКЕДСЧР ВХЯРН ОНКХРХВЕЯЙХЕ ЖЕКХ]. Gov.karelia.ru. Retrieved 26 July 2012. Bäckman has frequently travelled to Russia since 1993,{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/*/www.politika-karelia.ru/cgi-bin/articles_print.cgi?id=32 |date=* |title=Выродившаяся нация, у которой нет будущего }} and is fluent in [[Russian language|Russian]]. In 2000, he established a publishing institution named the ''Johan Beckman{{sic}} Institute'' in [[Saint Petersburg]].Publication index of Johan Beckman Institute http://www.ruslania.com/language-4/entity-1/context-289/publisher-1039.html In March 2002, during a military historical festival in [[Suojärvi]] in the [[Republic of Karelia]] which was dedicated to the 62nd anniversary of the end of the [[Winter War]], Bäckman made a sensational claim that the modern authorities of Finland propagated the idea that the Russian people are genetically inferior and expected Russia to collapse in about twenty years.{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/*/www.rep.ru/20Mar2002/society/01.html |date=* |title=РУССКИЕ ЛЮДИ ГЕНЕТИЧЕСКИ НЕПОЛНОЦЕННЫЕ? }} The other participants at the festival considered that he unreasonably overestimated the extent of [[anti-Russian sentiment]] in Finland.{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/*/www.rep.ru/10Apr2002/society/02.html |date=* |title=ВОЗМОЖНО, У ЙОХАНА БЭКМАНА НЕТ ЧУВСТВА ЮМОРА? }} According to Bäckman's article "Finland without a mask" (the title alludes to a 1943 proclamation by [[Otto Wille Kuusinen]]), published in Russian in May 2002, the Finns in general consider themselves a superior nation, all Russian women prostitutes, and all Russian men thieves and bandits.[http://whiteworld.ns-info.ru/rubriki/000108/006/02051703.htm RuWeb.Info - Белый Мир - Йохан Бэкман - Финляндия без маски]. Whiteworld.ns-info.ru. Retrieved 26 July 2012. During 2002, Bäckman gained an odious reputation both in Russia and among his Finnish colleagues.{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/*/www.politika-karelia.ru/shtml/article.shtml?id=28 |date=* |title=Поколение новое - предрассудки старые }} In 2003, Johan Beckman Institute published the book ''Finland and the Siege of Leningrad 1941-1944'' by the Russian historian [[Nikolai Baryshnikov]]. The [[Legislative Assembly of Saint Petersburg|Saint Petersburg legislature]] awarded Bäckman their ''Marshal Govorov Literature Prize'' (2003) for the book. Historian [[Timo Vihavainen]], a historian at the University of Helsinki described it as "a book built on [[Neo-Stalinism|Stalinist]] propaganda stereotypes". Vihavainen also said that Baryshnikov had misunderstood some of the language in Finnish archive documents.[http://www.sptimes.ru/index.php?action_id=2&story_id=9118 New Book on Siege Gets A Hot Finnish Response | The St. Petersburg Times | The leading English-language newspaper in St. Petersburg]. Sptimes.ru. Retrieved 26 July 2012. Bäckman and Baryshnikov threatened to sue Vihavainen. According to Finnish newspaper ''[[Helsingin Sanomat]]'', Johan Bäckman was a talented researcher in [[Russian studies]] in the early 2000s, who has since "marginalized" himself in Finland.{{cite news |title=Maailman paras maa |author= |first=Jussi |last=Konttinen |url=http://www.hs.fi/ulkomaat/artikkeli/Putin-nuoret+rinnastavat+suomalaistuomarin+natseihin/1135258810533 |agency= |newspaper=Helsingin Sanomat |date=25 June 2010 |pages=C4–C5 |language=Finnish |quote =only a part of the article is in the web.}} Bäckman serves [[Russian Institute for Strategic Studies]] (RISS) as representative in Northern Europe. RISS is a Russian state funded research group led by a former Soviet intelligence officer. === Bäckman's views of Vladimir Putin === [[File:Saatana Helsinkiin.jpg|thumb|220px|right|In the [[pamphlet]] ''Finland washed with Anna Politkovskaya's blood'', Bäckman accuses the Finnish media of anti-Russian and anti-Putin sentiment.]] In his 2007 book ''Finland washed with Anna Politkovskaya's blood'' ({{lang-fi|Saatana saapuu Helsinkiin}}, Literally: ''Satan Arrives in Helsinki'', which alludes to ''Saatana saapuu Moskovaan'', the Finnish language title for ''[[The Master and Margarita]]'' by [[Bulgakov]]) he supported the conspiracy theory that [[Assassination of Anna Politkovskaya|Anna Politkovskaya assassination]] was organized by as an attempt to smear the Russian president [[Vladimir Putin]]. Bäckman has hinted that Politkovskaya was depressed and ordered her own murder. According to Bäckman, Politkovskaya, a Russian writer and human rights activist, was an American agent. He also criticizes Finns' reaction to the murder. Bäckman accused Finnish [[Green League]] politician [[Heidi Hautala]] and the Finnish media of inciting hatred towards Russia and Vladimir Putin. Hautala, depicted on the book cover (''pictured''), saw this as a [[smear campaign]], but refused to take legal action, preferring to allow the book to speak for itself.[http://www.hs.fi/english/article/1135225486579 Helsingin Sanomat: Book accuses media and Green MP of inciting anti-Russian sentiment (1 March 2007)]. Hs.fi. Retrieved 26 July 2012. Bäckman admires Vladmir Putin, crediting all recent successes of Russia to Putin's personality and health.[http://www.apn-spb.ru/publications/article2329.htm АПН Северо-Запад / Я - не агент ФСБ!]. Apn-spb.ru. Retrieved 26 July 2012.[http://www.apn-spb.ru/publications/article2316.htm АПН Северо-Запад / Путин - как натянутый лук - пускает стрелу Амура прямо в сердце Европы]. Apn-spb.ru. Retrieved 26 July 2012. He has compared Putin to Cold War-era Finnish president [[Urho Kekkonen]], and claimed he wishes Putin would likewise rule Russia for 26 years. He stated that Finland also needs organizations such as the pro-Kremlin [[Nashi (youth movement)|Nashi]] and [[Walking Together]]. According to Bäckman, the [[freedom of the press in Russia]] is considerably higher than in Finland, and Estonia is not free at all. ===Bäckman in Russian media=== According to Finnish Academy chairman [[Arto Mustajoki]], Dr. Bäckman is five times more visible in the Russian media than previous Finnish premier [[Jyrki Katainen]] or previous president [[Tarja Halonen]]. According to Mustajoki, Russians treat Bäckman as "hero" because he defends Russian minorities in the Baltic States.Yliopisto No. 1/2013, p. 42 == Bäckman and Estonia == Bäckman's work has been published in Finland and Estonia. Many of his published opinions are provocative and some have been regarded as pro-Putin and [[Anti-Estonian sentiment|anti-Estonian]] by commentators in the Estonian press.[[Eesti Ekspress]] 23 February 2009 12:43: [http://www.ekspress.ee/2009/03/23/eesti-uudised/40505-raige-eesti-vastane-kampaania-kaib-kolmes-riigis-korraga Räige Eesti-vastane kampaania käib kolmes riigis korraga], edited by [[Askur Alas]] Bäckman has stated that Estonia "does not exist" as a sovereign state.[[ves.lv]] 6 March 2009 13:02: [http://www.ves.lv/article/72616 "Эстония? Нет такого государства!"], interview by [[Yelena Slyusareva]] According to Bäckman, the [[Estonians]] and [[Finns]] are actually one nation and the Republic of [[Estonia]] should be united with [[Finland]] where it could still have an autonomy.{{cite news |language=Estonian|first= |last= |title=Bäckman: Soome ja Eesti – üks rahvas – üks riik! |work= |page= |date=29 April 2009 |accessdate=30 April 2009 |quote= |url=http://www.eesti.ca/?op=article&articleid=23557 }} ===The Bronze Soldier book=== In his highly controversial book about the Estonian [[Bronze Soldier]] ''Pronssisoturi: Viron patsaskiistan tausta ja sisältö'', published in Finnish in 2008, Bäckman disagrees with the integration policies of [[Estonia]]. In his opinion, Estonian integration policies that have seen some 147,000 Russian speakers receiving Estonian citizenship in the past decade are "[[apartheid]]" and represent a "criminal discrimination of Russians". In the ''Bronze Soldier'' he dismissed the [[Soviet occupation of Estonia]] as a "Nazi myth".[http://www.hs.fi/kulttuuri/artikkeli/1135239739349 Helsingin yliopisto ei puutu Bäckmanin puheisiin - HS.fi - Kulttuuri]. HS.fi. Retrieved 26 July 2012. Bäckman has gained publicity in Estonia for denying the Soviet occupation during 1940-1941 and 1944-1991:
''"In my opinion speaking or writing of Soviet "occupation" should be criminalised as a form of racist propaganda.
In connection to the publication of the book in September 2008, Bäckman gave several interviews, including one in which he claimed Estonia will join Russia within a decade.[http://www.dzd.ee/?SID=688cc57e4703df2db609bbc5da87b9e2&n=17&a=2790 Десять лет, которые потрясут Эстонию] [[Den' za Dnyom]] {{ru icon}}{{cite web|title=Estland in zehn Jahren Teil der Russischen Föderation|publisher=[[Der Standard]]|url=http://derstandard.at/?url=/?id=1220457806736|date=11 September 2008|accessdate=13 September 2008|language=de}}[http://epl.ee/?uudised=438161 Bäckman: Eesti on teel otse põrgusse] [[Eesti Päevaleht]] 11 August 2008 {{et icon}}[http://www.balticbusinessnews.com/Default2.aspx?ref=topread&ArticleID=becc1bf7-ae5f-44bf-b9c9-74824c98cd26 Finnish writer: Estonia to lose independence in 10 years] [[Baltic Business News]] 11 August 2008[http://www.moles.ee/08/Aug/15/11-1.php Эстония прямиком движется в ад] [[Molodezh Estonii]] 15 August 2008 Bäckman also claimed that the "destruction" of the Bronze Soldier grave site and monument in April 2007 by the Estonian government was "the end of history of Estonia". He speculated that most of the Russian youth all over Russia, including children, hate Estonia and deny her the right to exist. Bäckman went on to predict that in ten years at most, the [[Nashi (youth movement)|Nashi]] would come to power in Russia, leading to an end of the Estonian statehood shortly afterwards. After the publication of the book, Finnish and Estonian cultural figures, scholars, journalists and politicians, including [[Henrik Lax]], [[Lasse Lehtinen]] and [[Sofi Oksanen]], addressed the [[University of Helsinki]] in an [[open letter]] of protest, partly in relation to Bäckman teaching a course on "specialities of Estonian legal policy" in the Spring 2009 semester.[http://www.hs.fi/kulttuuri/artikkeli/1135239710765 Avoin kirje vaatii Bäckmanin opetuksen tutkintaa Helsingin yliopistossa - HS.fi - Kulttuuri]. HS.fi. Retrieved 26 July 2012. Bäckman immediately threatened to sue the letter's authors for libel and later filed a criminal complaint, but the Helsinki Police refused to open investigation.{{fi icon}} [http://www.uusisuomi.fi/kulttuuri/40079-poliisi-tyrmasi-dosentin-epailyt Poliisi tyrmäsi dosentin epäilyt]. Uusisuomi.fi (4 November 2008). Retrieved 26 July 2012. The former minister of foreign affairs of Finland Dr. [[Erkki Tuomioja]] called Bäckman's book as "deliberate provocation", but condemned the open letter for violating the principles of freedom of speech.{{cite web| url=http://www.tuomioja.org/index.php?mainAction=showPage&id=1553&category=3 | title=Pitäisikö provosoitua? | author=Tuomioja, Erkki | authorlink=Erkki Tuomioja |date = October 2008| accessdate=31 March 2009}} The University of Helsinki distanced itself in a statement holding that Bäckman's political views are his own and do not represent the University's.[http://www.postimees.ee/?id=99995 Helsingi ülikool distantseerus Bäckmani seisukohtadest] [[Postimees]] 27 March 2008 {{et icon}} ===Nashi protests in Helsinki=== [[File:Nashidemonstration-helsinki-2009.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Bäckman arranged the "[[Nashi (youth movement)|Nashi]]-protest" on 23 March 2009. The handful of demonstrators were the focus of attention for about 40 representatives of the media.[http://www.hs.fi/english/article/Hundreds+of+listeners+and+a+handful+of+protesters+attend+publication+of+book+on+Estonia/1135244564138 Helsingin Sanomat: Hundreds of listeners and a handful of protesters attend publication of book on Estonia (24 March 2007)]. Hs.fi. Retrieved 26 July 2012.]] In March 2009 Bäckman, as part of the [[Finnish Anti-Fascist Committee]], arranged a series of protests in Helsinki attended by activists of the Russian [[Nashi (youth movement)|Nashi]], and [[Nochnoy Dozor (pressure group)|Night Watch]] organizations, against what they called the "opening [of] a new anti-Russian front of information warfare on the territory of Finland by [the] Estonian embassy." In addition, [[Abdullah Tammi]] and his followers from the prospective [[Finnish Islamic Party]] participated. The protests were aimed against seminars, against a book about the [[Soviet occupation of Estonia]], and against films presented by the Estonian embassy in Finland, especially the film ''[[Soviet Story]]'' by [[Edvins Snore]]. In media commentaries for Swedish, Finnish and Russian press, television and radio, Bäckman claimed that the Soviet Union did not occupy Estonia, and belittled the significance of the [[Soviet deportations from Estonia]]. ===Estonian Internal Security Service and Bäckman=== The [[Estonian Internal Security Service|Estonian Internal Security Service (Kaitsepolitseiamet)]] official Andres Kahar said in the Estonian press that Bäckman is "a Russian propagandist" spreading disinformation similar to claims made in Moscow.{{cite web|url=http://www.sloleht.ee/index.aspx?id=296973 |title=Kapo: milleks aidata Vene propagandamasinat? |author=Viivik, Allar |work=SL Õhtuleht |date=23 March 2008 |accessdate=26 September 2008 |language=et }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{Cite journal | journal = [[Eesti Ekspress]] | date= 18 March 2009 | url = http://www.ekspress.ee/2009/03/18/eesti-uudised/40449-yheskoos-eesti-vastu-antifashist-backman-ja-natsimeelne-teinonen | title = Üheskoos Eesti vastu: antifašist Bäckman ja natsimeelne Teinonen | author = Askur Alas|accessdate=31 March 2009 | language = et }}{{cite web|url=http://www.axisglobe.com/article.asp?article=1661|title=Eurasian Secret Services Daily Review|first=1 October 2008|work=Global Challenges Research|accessdate=15 April 2010}} In March 2009, the newspaper ''[[Eesti Ekspress]]'' reported a link between Bäckman and the Finnish neo-nazi [[Risto Teinonen]], alleging both of them are connected to the reputed former [[KGB]] agent [[Vladimir Ilyashevich]] residing in Estonia, all of whom are linked to the Russian historian [[Alexander Dyukov (historian)|Alexander Dyukov]]. In the assessment by [[Estonian Internal Security Service|Kaitsepolitseiamet]], Bäckman, Teinonen and Ilyashevich are working as a team with support from Moscow, attempting to undermine the names of many good people, the relations between Finland and Estonia, and the Republic of Estonia itself. Finnish counter-intelligence has not commented on Bäckman publicly. Regarding [[Nashi (youth movement)|Nashi]]-demonstrations organised by Bäckman in Helsinki in March 2009, the Finnish security police spokesman replied they heard "rumours" about the demonstrations but would not comment on issues regarding free democratic activism.http://www.uusisuomi.fi/kotimaa/53880-supo-nashien-helsingin-retkesta-”olemme-kuulleet-huhuja” ===''Persona non grata'' status in Estonia=== On 26 April 2009, Bäckman was detained after his disembarkation from a ferry in the [[Tallinn Passenger Port]] and expelled from the country under an entry prohibition. The Estonian Ministry of Internal Affairs confirmed that Johan Bäckman has been declared ''persona non grata'' in Estonia.{{cite news|url=http://www.hs.fi/english/article/Anti-Estonian+Johan+Bäckman+refused+entry+at+Port+of+Tallinn/1135245495868|title=Anti-Estonian Johan Bäckman refused entry at Port of Tallinn|date=27 April 2009|work=[[Helsingin Sanomat]]|accessdate=30 May 2014}} Among reasons for expulsion, the [[Estonian Minister of Internal Affairs]] listed the first of all twelve statements by Bäckman in the Estonian press and in his blog, claiming Estonia is an "[[apartheid]]" regime that "falsifies" history. [[Helsingin Sanomat]] pointed out such prohibition against entry into Estonia by Finnish citizens is extremely rare. Previously such entry bans have been issued to some Finns suspected of connections with racist movements.{{Cite journal | title = Anti-Estonian Johan Bäckman refused entry at Port of Tallinn | journal = [[Helsingin Sanomat]] | date = 27 April 2009 | accessdate =28 April 2009 | url = http://www.hs.fi/english/article/Anti-Estonian+Johan+B%C3%A4ckman+refused+entry+at+Port+of+Tallinn/1135245495868 }} In December 2010, Tallinn regional court declared entry prohibitions against Bäckman illegal and ordered the Ministry of Internal Affairs to compensate his legal fees in sum of 16,600 [[Estonian kroon]]s.[http://www.uudised.err.ee/index.php?06221060 Johan Bäckman seljatas kohtus Eesti riigi | ERR Uudised]. Uudised.err.ee (17 December 2010). Retrieved 26 July 2012. On 29 July 2011, Bäckman was again denied entry into Estonia and sent back to Finland.{{cite web |url=http://www.uudised.err.ee/index.php?06232213 |title=Bäckman was sent back to Finland |author=Priit Burbot |date=30 July 2011 |work= |publisher=ERR |accessdate=4 January 2012}} == Bäckman and Finland == Bäckman has been a commentator of Finnish-Russian child custody and "grandmother cases". The Finnish Broadcasting Company [[Yle]], quoting [[Timo Vihavainen]], a professor of Russian history, speculated that this has happened due to fact that Bäckman's opinions match the interests of the Kremlin.{{cite web | title = Professori: Kohudosenttiin suhtauduttava vakavasti | url = http://yle.fi/uutiset/kotimaa/2010/06/professori_kohudosenttiin_suhtauduttava_vakavasti_1734417.html | publisher = [[Yle]] | date = 8 June 2010 | accessdate=8 June 2010 | language = fi }} Bäckman was a commentator for Russian press during the [[Anton incident]] in 2009.[http://www.iltasanomat.fi/uutiset/kotimaa/uutinen.asp?id=1740651 Iltasanomat: Antonin äiti: Tuomio on epäoikeudenmukainen - katso video] (in Finnish)[http://en.rian.ru/russia/20091013/156452360.html RIA Novosti: Russian woman convicted of kidnapping own son in Finland]. En.rian.ru (13 October 2009). Retrieved 26 July 2012. Later, Bäckman apologized for his behaviour, and promised not to further intervene in the incident.{{cite web | url = http://www.hs.fi/english/article/B%C3%A4ckman+apologises+to+Paavo+Salonen+over+comments+on+child+custody+affair/1135250237739 | title = Bäckman apologises to Paavo Salonen over comments on child custody affair | accessdate =15 November 2010 | publisher = [[Helsingin Sanomat]]}}[http://antonfree.blogspot.com/2009/10/johan-backmanin-julkinen-anteeksipyynto.html Johan Bäckman: Johan Bäckmanin julkinen anteeksipyyntö Paavo Saloselle] (in Finnish) However, he later deleted his apology, continuing to comment on the case.http://kohudosentti.blogspot.fi/2010/08/suomi-kielsi-anton-saloselta-venajan.html He was also an active commentator for Russian press during the [[Rantala incident]] in 2010.{{cite web| url = http://www.kommersant.ru/doc.aspx?fromsearch=8ad49230-07a2-412b-95f6-5a377c7e9d6f&docsid=1338490 | script-title=ru:Бронзовый мальчик | accessdate =27 March 2010 | publisher = [[Kommersant]] | language = ru}} Bäckman also received media time with grandmother and similar child custody cases in 2010. Bäckman claims that children that are being taken care of by Finnish child protection authorities are living in "concentration camps", and explains that "this is a certain system of political terror". To explain why the rest of the world has not noticed this, he claims that "Children who get into these camps have special prohibitions for communications, they cannot tell us what is happening there." He states that "I think that the juvenile justice system, the system of a mass removal of children, is genocide of children.". He has not provided numbers for how many children are supposed to have been killed in this alleged "genocide", and has not revealed any sources for his information.http://english.pravda.ru/society/family/28-01-2014/126694-finland_juvenile_fascism-0/ Bäckman has criticized [[Yle]] journalist [[Jessikka Aro]], who investigated pro-Russian [[Internet troll]]s, accusing her in “Russo-phobic” tendencies and claiming that she was "well-known assistant of American and Baltic special services."{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/31/world/europe/russia-finland-nato-trolls.html |title=Effort to Expose Russia’s ‘Troll Army’ Draws Vicious Retaliation |first=Andrew|last=Higgins |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=30 May 2015 |accessdate=2016-10-27| ref=nyt}} Prosecutors have formally charged Bäckman for harassment and aggravated defamation of Aro.{{cite news |url=https://yle.fi/uutiset/osasto/news/controversial_academic_charged_over_harassment_slander_of_yle_journalist/10134347 |title=Controversial academic charged over harassment, slander of Yle journalist |publisher=[[Yle]] |date=26 March 2018 |accessdate=2018-07-02}} In October 2018 Bäckman received a 12-month suspended jail sentence for aggravated defamation and stalking. Bäckman said he would appeal the verdict.{{cite news |last1=Higgins |first1=Andrew |title=Three Internet Trolls Convicted of Systematic Defamation Against Journalist in Finland |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/19/world/europe/finland-internet-trolls-defamation.html |accessdate=21 October 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=19 October 2018}} Bäckman has a background in music. According to Helsingin Sanomat he became a public figure in the late 1980s when playing the [[bassoon]] in the EBU Young Soloists Competition on national television. Bäckman also played the bassoon in the Finnish Radio Symphony Orchestra. == Bäckman and Ukraine == In March 2014 Bäckman was invited to participate as observer by the [[Eurasian Observatory for Democracy & Elections]] (EODE),{{cite web |url=http://zpravy.aktualne.cz/domaci/ani-pusky-ani-natlak-jak-cesti-politici-dohlizeli-na-krymu/r~d5764000aee911e3a322002590604f2e/ |title=Politici jeli na Krym s extremisty. Bylo to narychlo, říkají |author=Sandra Štefaniková|publisher=Aktuálně.cz |date=2014-03-19| accessdate = 2014-03-20}}{{cite web |url=http://www.lidovky.cz/berkovcova-mise-na-krym-mlzil-o-nazvu-organizatora-i-financovani-phh-/zpravy-domov.aspx?c=A140319_171408_ln_domov_spa| title= Berkovcova mise na Krym. Tají organizátora i financování| author = spa (Šárka Pálková) |publisher=Lidovky.cz| date = 2014-03-20| accessdate = 2014-03-22}} a far-right Russia-based self-proclaimed election monitoring organization,{{cite journal | url=http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/141067/mitchell-a-orenstein/putins-western-allies | title=Putin's Western Allies. Why Europe's Far Right Is on the Kremlin's Side | author=Orenstein, Mitchell | journal=Foreign Affairs |date=March 2014 }} in disputed [[Crimean status referendum, 2014|Crimean status referendum]] which resulted [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|annexation of Crimea by Russia]]. Bäckman stated that he saw no violations and considered the referendum to be within the framework of international law.{{cite news|url=http://www.europeanbusinessreview.eu/page.asp?pid=1193 |last=Banks |first=Martin |title=International election monitors refuted suggestions of violations in the Crimean referendum |publisher=European Business Review |date=18 March 2014 |accessdate=2014-07-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714150218/http://www.europeanbusinessreview.eu/page.asp?pid=1193 |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df= }} In May he announced that separatist [[Donetsk People's Republic]] will open a representative office in Helsinki.{{cite news |url=http://yle.fi/uutiset/ukrainian_separatists_opening_mission_in_helsinki/7226818 |title=Ukrainian separatists opening mission in Helsinki |publisher=[[Yle]] |date=7 May 2014 |accessdate=2014-07-06}} Bäckman claims that [[Malaysia Airlines Flight 17]] shootdown was a United States provocation to justify a NATO intervention in [[War in Donbass|Donbass conflict]], and describes Ukrainian government as "the Kiev junta".{{cite news |url=http://en.ria.ru/burning_point/20140805/191768221/US-and-NATO-Up-for-New-Anti-Russia-Provocation-This-Time-in-The.html |title=US and NATO Up for New Anti-Russia Provocation, This Time in The Baltic - Expert |publisher=[[RIA Novosti]] |date=5 August 2014 |accessdate=2014-08-05}} == Bäckman and Moldova == In May 2014 Bäckman was expelled from [[Moldova]] and received five-year entry ban, as his activities were regarded as undermining Moldova's statehood.{{cite news|url=http://www.interfax.com/newsinf.asp?id=509704 |title=Finnish human rights activist Backman deported from Moldova, banned entry for five years |publisher=[[Interfax]] |date=29 May 2014 |accessdate=2014-06-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714214033/http://www.interfax.com/newsinf.asp?id=509704 |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df= }} == Politics == Bäckman regards the [[Taistolaisuus|Taistoists]] movement of the 1970s, the hardline pro-Soviet faction in the [[Communist Party of Finland]], as "the best thing that happened in the history of Finland". He has said: "We can thank the Taistoists for high-quality science, art and culture we enjoy today".{{cite news|url=http://www.hbl.fi/text/inrikes/2009/3/22/d25126.php |title=Han bjöd in 30 Putinunga |publisher=[[Hufvudstadsbladet]] |date=22 March 2009 |accessdate=29 March 2009 |last=Bruun |first=Staffan |language=sv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090326042650/http://www.hbl.fi/text/inrikes/2009/3/22/d25126.php |archivedate=26 March 2009 |df= }} Bäckman was an [[Independent (politician)|independent candidate]] for [[European Parliament election, 2009 (Finland)|European Parliament election in 2009]] on the [[Workers Party of Finland]] list. He got 554 votes and was not allocated a seat.{{cite news |url=http://192.49.229.35/EP2009/s/tulos/ehdtulos_kokomaa.html |title=EUROPARLAMENTTIVAALIT 7.6.2009 - Tulos - Koko maa |publisher=vaalit.fi (the Official Results by the Ministry of Justice) |accessdate=13 June 2009 |last= |first= |language=fi |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090612060746/http://192.49.229.35/EP2009/s/tulos/ehdtulos_kokomaa.html |archivedate=12 June 2009 |df=dmy-all }} In March 2011, Bäckman announced that he is a candidate for the [[Finnish parliamentary election, 2011|2011 Finnish parliamentary election]] on the Workers Party of Finland list.[http://www.iltasanomat.fi/vaalit2011/Huoltajuuskiistasta%20tuttu%20Rimma%20Salonen%20pyrkii%20eduskuntaan/art-1288373373617.html Iltasanomat: Huoltajuuskiistasta tuttu Rimma Salonen pyrkii eduskuntaan]. Iltasanomat.fi (3 March 2011). Retrieved 26 July 2012.[http://antifasistit.blogspot.com/2011/03/jussi-parviainen-johan-backman-juha.html Safka blogi: Jussi Parviainen, Johan Bäckman, Juha Molari, Rimma Salonen ovat SAFKAn eduskuntavaaliehdokkaat!]. Antifasistit.blogspot.com. Retrieved 26 July 2012. He gained only 36 votes and was not allocated a seat.[http://192.49.229.35/E2011/e/tulos/ehdkutulos_helsinki.html Electoral district of Helsinki] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928082454/http://192.49.229.35/E2011/e/tulos/ehdkutulos_helsinki.html |date=28 September 2011 }} Official results of Finnish Justice Ministry In October 2012 he was a candidate in municipal elections in [[Espoo]], getting 43 votes, insufficient to gain a seat.http://vaalit.yle.fi/tulospalvelu/2012/kuntavaalit/ehdokkaat/ehdokas_2_49_582.html Yle results of candidate Bäckman, Johan == Academic career == He received his training in [[sociology]] at the [[University of Helsinki]], where he defended his Ph.D. in 2006,[http://ethesis.helsinki.fi/julkaisut/val/sosio/vk/backman/abstract.html Johan Bäckman: Itämafia]. Ethesis.helsinki.fi. Retrieved 26 July 2012. and has a title of a [[docent]] (not an indication of a teaching position or employment){{cite web|url=http://www.rectors-council.helsinki.fi/lausunnot_ja_kannanotot/lausunnot_2010/Unifi_suositus_DosentinArvoEnglanniksi.pdf |title=Dosentin arvon englanninkielinen käännös |language=Finnish |trans-title=Translation of the title of docent into English |last1=Lajunen |first1=Lauri |last2=Savunen |first2=Liisa |date=11 February 2010 |work= |publisher=Suomen yliopistot – Finlands universitet – Universities Finland UNIFI |accessdate=11 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523220245/http://www.rectors-council.helsinki.fi/lausunnot_ja_kannanotot/lausunnot_2010/Unifi_suositus_DosentinArvoEnglanniksi.pdf |archivedate=23 May 2013 |df= }} of the [[sociology of law]].[http://www.helsinki.fi/rpol/esittely/henkilosto.htm Oikeustieteellinen tiedekunta]. Helsinki.fi. Retrieved 26 July 2012. He also has a title of a [[docent]] in criminology at the [[University of Turku]][http://notes.utu.fi/ty/webexper.nsf/031b9e8464cecb05c22564dd003abe2e/9b3aa972eae3fe4ec22573b700208d2b?OpenDocument Asiantuntija: Johan Bäckman] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081017182219/http://notes.utu.fi/ty/webexper.nsf/031b9e8464cecb05c22564dd003abe2e/9b3aa972eae3fe4ec22573b700208d2b?OpenDocument |date=17 October 2008 }}. Notes.utu.fi (13 May 2008). Retrieved 26 July 2012. and the [[University of Eastern Finland]]. He has previously taught courses on the sociology of law, criminology, and Russian studies in several Finnish universities. == Private life == Johan Bäckman is a son of ''Erkki Bäckman'' who was a [[Managing Director]] of [[Hartwall]] beverage company.{{cite news|url=http://www.delfi.ee/news/paevauudised/valismaa/johan-backmani-isa-teenis-mullu-17-miljonit-eurot.d?id=26733007|title=Johan Bäckmani isa teenis mullu 1,7 miljonit eurot|date=6 November 2009|work=[[Delfi (web portal)|Delfi]]|language=Estonian|accessdate=28 July 2010}} Johan Bäckman has litigated over child custody against his Soviet-born ex-wife for years in which both parties have received sentences for [[libel]]. {{cite journal |last1=Mäkinen |first1=Esa |title=Johan on kumma! |journal=Helsingin Sanomat |issue= |pages=C1 |date=6 December 2010 |language= fi }}http://www.hs.fi/kotimaa/Johan+B%C3%A4ckman+on+kiistellyt+Neuvostoliitossa+syntyneen+ex-puolisonsa+kanssa+lapsensa+huoltajuudesta/a1305608123204?ref=fb-share Bäckman's current family consists of a girl and two boys. His wife is a [[Russian language]] and [[Russian literature|literature]] teacher.{{cite journal|last1=Грибанова |first1=Татьяна |year=2010 |script-title=ru:Йохан Бекман: Моё хобби - это Россия |journal=Аиф Тамбов |volume= |issue=32 (790) |pages= |publisher= |doi= |url=http://tambov.aif.ru/issues/790/02_01 |accessdate=6 December 2010 |language=ru |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110830121231/http://tambov.aif.ru/issues/790/02_01 |archivedate=30 August 2011 |df= }} According to Helsingin Sanomat, Bäckman had been treated with caution in the Finnish public media because he is sensitive to what he considers to be journalistic libels. According to the newspaper he has won a court case two times, but equally self-convicted of libel in July 2009. Bäckman wrote a letter to the editor saying he had won seven libel cases during past couple of years, not two, as the paper claimed. Bäckman wrote he won the cases against five persons, all of whom are female citizens of Finland.Helsingin Sanomat 16 December 2010 Bäckman has a child from the previous relationship with '''Jaana Niemi'''. Niemi was born in the Soviet Union with Finnish origins, but was brought up in Russian culture. The family also spoke Finnish. In 1990, Niemi, then age of 15, moved from the Soviet Union to Finland. Bäckman and Niemi's relationship lasted six months and ended in a confrontational way. A daughter was born in 2004. Soon after, Bäckman sued Jaana Niemi, her parents and friends dozens of times. Most of cases ended in pretrial investigations, but Bäckman run a few cases by himself in a court. The Finnish court [[Hovioikeus]] convicted Niemi once, and Bäckman was convicted twice. Niemi lives now in [[Milan]], [[Italy]].{{cite news |url=http://www.hs.fi/sunnuntai/B%C3%A4ckmanin+ex-naisyst%C3%A4v%C3%A4n+perheen+piina+jatkunut+kahdeksan+vuotta/a1354342057842 |title= Bäckmanin Amir M
Amir Abtol Rahman
Amir Kuptu
Amir Humam Abdul Najid | foundation = 2011 | dates = {{Start date|2011}}–2013 | dissolved = 2013 | merger = | split = | predecessor = | merged = [[Maute Group]] | successor = | motives = | area = [[Central Mindanao]] | ideology = [[Islamic extremism|Radical]] [[Islamism]] | position = | crimes = | attacks = | status = | size = ''unknown'' | revenue = | financing = | flag = [[File:AQMI Flag asymmetric.svg|150px]] | website = }} '''Khalifa Islamiyah Mindanao''' ('''KIM''') was a dedicated organization that sought to establish an independent state in [[Mindanao]], [[Philippines]]. The group was led by an Afghan-trained cleric known as Humam Abdul Najid.{{cite web | last =Chalk | first =Peter | title =The Islamic State in the Philippines: A Looming Shadow in Southeast Asia? | url=https://www.ctc.usma.edu/posts/the-islamic-state-in-the-philippines-a-looming-shadow-in-southeast-asia | accessdate = May 28, 2016}} It was sometimes described as an [[umbrella organization]] composed of the [[Jemaah Islamiyah]], the [[Abu Sayyaf]], and members of other armed groups. According to the [[Philippine Institute for Peace, Violence and Terrorism Research]], the KIM had five founders; [[Zulkifli Abdhir]], who was killed on January 25, 2015 by [[Special Action Force]] officers during the raid that culminated in the [[Mamasapano clash]], Amir M, Amir Abtol Rahman, Amir Kuptu and Amir Humam Abdul Najid. The group has reportedly adopted the flag of the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]].{{cite news|last1=Medina|first1=Andrei|title=Marwan was only one of the leaders of Khalifa Islamiyah Mindanao|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/440506/news/nation/marwan-was-only-one-of-the-leaders-of-khalifa-islamiyah-mindanao|accessdate=February 19, 2015|publisher=GMA News|date=February 18, 2015}} [[Armed Forces of the Philippines]] chief, [[Emmanuel Bautista]] confirmed the existence of the group in August 2013, although reports about the group were made as early as two years before.{{cite news|last1=Laude|first1=Jaime|title=AFP chief confirms new militant group in South|url=http://www.philstar.com/nation/2013/08/29/1145031/afp-chief-confirms-new-militant-group-south|accessdate=February 19, 2015|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=August 29, 2013}}{{cite news | last =Ramos | first =Marlon | title =AFP, MILF join forces to hunt down new terror group in Mindanao | publisher =''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]'' | date = August 29, 2013 | url =http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/476661/afp-milf-join-forces-to-hunt-down-new-terror-group-in-mindanao | accessdate = May 28, 2016}} ==See also== * [[Peace process with the Bangsamoro in the Philippines]] * [[Insurgency in the Philippines]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{History of the Moro conflict}} {{Southern Philippines Insurgency}} {{IslamismSEA}} {{Portal bar|War|Terrorism|Philippines}} [[Category:Jihadist groups]] [[Category:Military history of the Philippines]] [[Category:Islamism in the Philippines]] [[Category:Separatism in the Philippines]] [[Category:Secessionist organizations in Asia]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2011]] {{Terrorism-stub}} {{Philippines-stub}}

|twin1_country = }} '''Khao-I-Dang Holding Center''' was a [[Khmer people|Cambodian]] [[refugee]] camp located 20 km north of [[Aranyaprathet]] in [[Prachinburi Province|Prachinburi]] (now [[Sa Kaeo Province|Sa Kaeo]]) Province of [[Thailand]]. The most enduring [[refugee camp]] on the Thai-Cambodian border, it was established in late 1979 and administered by the Thai Ministry of the Interior and the [[United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees]] (UNHCR) -- unlike other camps on the border, which were administered by a coalition made up of [[UNICEF]], the [[World Food Program]], [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] (ICRC) (briefly) and, after 1982, the [[United Nations Border Relief Operation]] (UNBRO).
== Camp Construction == Situated on the sparsely wooded plains in eastern Thailand a few miles from the Cambodian border, the huge compound of [[bamboo]] and [[thatch]] houses was opened on November 21, 1979 after the fall of the [[Khmer Rouge]].<ref>[http://www.worldandischool.com/public/1987/March/school-resource12767.asp Khao-I-Dang and the Conscience of the West - John Bowles]</ref> Following the establishment of an emergency camp for refugees at [[Sa Kaeo Refugee Camp|Sa Kaeo]], the Thai Ministry of the Interior authorized [[Mark Malloch Brown]] of the UNHCR to build a second camp at the foot of Khao-I-Dang Mountain.
According to Martin Barber, Chief of UNHCR's Kampuchean Unit, "The site, covering an area of 2.3 square kilometers on a gently sloping hill, had good drainage. It opened...after just four days of preparatory work spent in establishing the overall design of the camp and developing the basic infrastructure (roads, [http://www.websitesrcg.com/border/photos/kid/ChhanTouch/811620-R1-E002.jpg water tanks], and latrines) of the first "chunk".<ref>Barber M. "Operating a United Nations Program: A Reflection". In: Levy BS, Susott DC, editors. ''Years of horror, days of hope: responding to the Cambodian refugee crisis''. Millwood, N.Y.: Associated Faculty Press, 1987, p. 32 [https://www.amazon.com/Years-Horror-Days-Hope-Responding/dp/080469396X]</ref> The camp was divided into sections of 10,000-12,000 people. Each section had space allocated for reasonable housing and for necessary services including supplementary feeding.<ref>[http://www.websitesrcg.com/border/documents/Cambodian-Emergency-Refugee-Health-Care-1979-1980.pdf Allegra DT, Nieburg P, Grabe M, Centers for Disease C. ''Emergency refugee health care: a chronicle of the Khmer refugee-assistance operation, 1979-1980''. Atlanta, Ga.: Centers for Disease Control, 1984, p. 77.]</ref>
== Camp population == On October 19, 1979 Thai Prime Minister [[Kriangsak Chomanan]] enacted an "open door" policy which permitted Cambodian refugees to cross the border safely and to reside in specific locations.<ref>[http://forcedmigration.ccnmtl.columbia.edu/9-open-door "Thailand's Open-Door Policy,"]</ref><ref name=Shawcross>{{cite book|last1=Shawcross|first1=William|title=The Quality of Mercy: Cambodia, Holocaust, and Modern Conscience'|date=1984|publisher=Simon and Schuster|location=New York}}</ref>{{RP|173}} Khao-I-Dang (known to aid agencies as KID) was intended to serve as a temporary holding center for refugees who would either be repatriated to Cambodia or expatriated to third countries. On the first day 4,800 people arrived and by December 31 there were 84,800.<ref>Barber, in Levy and Susott, p. 32</ref> Between November 1979 and the end of January 1980 an average of 1,600 refugees arrived in the camp each day.<ref>[http://forcedmigration.ccnmtl.columbia.edu/11-khao-i-dang "Khao-I-Dang"]</ref> Thailand's open door policy was abruptly ended on January 24, 1980<ref name=Shawcross />{{RP|251}} and KID was "closed" to new arrivals.
Originally planned to hold 300,000 refugees,<ref>[http://www.websitesrcg.com/border/documents/Cambodian-Emergency-Refugee-Health-Care-1979-1980.pdf Allegra, Nieburg and Grabe, p. 5.]</ref> the population eventually reached 160,000 in March 1980.<ref>Mason, L. and R. Brown, ''Rice, Rivalry, and Politics: Managing Cambodian Relief''. 1983, Notre Dame [Ind.]: University of Notre Dame Press, p. 88</ref> Later, as KID became the main holding center for refugees awaiting third country visas, [[illegal entry]] to the camp became highly sought after by refugees desperate to escape from Cambodia, and smuggling, theft and violence spiraled out of control.<ref>Lawyers Committee for Human Rights (U.S.), ''Seeking shelter: Cambodians in Thailand: a report on human rights''. 1987, New York: Lawyers Committee for Human Rights.</ref> In July and August 1980 UNHCR began transferring large numbers of refugees out of KID to Phanat Nikhom, Sa Kaeo II, Mairut, and Kap Choeng.<ref>Carney TM. ''Kampuchea, balance of survival''. Bangkok: Distributed in Asia by DD Books, 1981, p. 14.</ref> By December 1982 the population had dropped to 40,134<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00000123.htm "Surveillance of Health Status of Kampuchean Refugees at Khao-I-Dang Holding Center, Thailand." CDC: MMWR of Aug 12, 1983 / 32(31);412-5]</ref> as refugees were [[refoulement|forcibly repatriated]], sent to third countries, or sent back to the border camps.<ref name=Shawcross />
===Camp residents=== The presence at Khao-I-Dang of a large number of refugees with education and experience in administration, health, teaching, or technical skills reduced the language problems and allowed early involvement of refugees in all fields of activities.<ref>[http://www.websitesrcg.com/border/documents/Cambodian-Emergency-Refugee-Health-Care-1979-1980.pdf Grabe, Magnus, "Organization of Khao-I-Dang Center, November 1979-January 1980," in Allegra, Nieburg and Grabe, p. 16.]</ref>
[[File:Khao I Dang gate.JPG|thumb|right|340px|Khao-I-Dang entrance, as seen from Thai National Hwy 348, May 1984. In the background is Khao-I-Dang Mountain; to the right is one of two water towers which stored water for the camp.]]
Many Cambodians recall spending some time at KID, including Dr [[Haing S. Ngor]] of [[The Killing Fields]], who (as a refugee) was employed in 1979 in the 400-bed ICRC hospital. The final scene in the movie was filmed at KID in 1983, in the surgical ward where Dr. Ngor had worked.<ref>Ngor, H. and R. Warner, ''Surviving the Killing Fields: The Cambodian Odyssey of Haing S. Ngor''. 1988: Chatto & Windus.</ref> Former refugees who have described their experiences in Khao-I-Dang include Molyda Szymusiak,<ref>Szymusiak M. ''The stones cry out: a Cambodian childhood, 1975-1980''. 1st ed. New York: Hill and Wang, 1986.</ref> Chanrithy Him,<ref>Him C. ''When broken glass floats: growing up under the Khmer Rouge, a memoir''. 1st ed. New York: W.W. Norton, 2000.</ref> Oni Vitandham<ref>Vitandham O. ''On the Wings of a White Horse: a Cambodian Princess's Story of Surviving the Khmer Rouge Genocide.'' Mustang, OK.: Tate Publishing, 2005</ref> and Mohm Phat.<ref>Sheehy G. ''Spirit of survival''. 1st ed. New York: Morrow, 1986.</ref>
== Camp services == [[File:Trucks unload food at KID.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Trucks unload food at Khao-I-Dang. Photo by Chhan Touch
[http://www.websitesrcg.com/border/photos/kid/ChhanTouch/811620-R1-E007.jpg].]]Provision of adequate food and water was a major logistical problem. Water was brought in each day by trucks from supply areas 1–2 hours away (l0-15 liters/person/day in the camp and 50-60 liters/hospitalized patient/day).<ref>Grabe, p. 16.</ref>
Educational and medical services were provided by Thai and international relief organizations.<ref>[http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0014/001493/149379eo.pdf Suenobu, Yumiko, "Management of education systems in zones of conflict-relief operations: a case-study in Thailand," 1995]</ref> KID soon became the most serviced camp on the Thai-Cambodian border; indeed, it was probably the most elaborately serviced refugee camp in the world.<ref>[http://repository.forcedmigration.org/show_metadata.jsp?pid=fmo:590 Rogge J, ''Return to Cambodia: the significance and implications of past, present, and future spontaneous repatriations''. Dallas, Tex.: Intertect Institute, 1990.]</ref> By early 1980, 37 voluntary agencies were working in the camp.<ref name=Shawcross />{{RP|242}} Most health services were provided by ICRC, [[Doctors Without Borders]], the [[Thai Red Cross]], [[CARE (relief agency)|CARE]], Irish [[Concern Worldwide|Concern]], [[Catholic Relief Services]], the [[International Rescue Committee]], the [[American Refugee Committee]], [[Christian and Missionary Alliance]], [[OXFAM]], [[Handicap International]], [[Malteser International]], and [[YWAM]].<ref>[http://repository.forcedmigration.org/show_metadata.jsp?pid=fmo:590 Suenobu, pp. 42-43.]</ref><ref>CCSDPT. ''The CCSDPT Handbook: Refugee Services in Thailand.'' Bangkok: Craftsman Press, 1983.</ref>
===Camp hospital=== ICRC chose KID for their first border [http://www.peshawar.ch/portfolio/portfolio-6.htm surgical hospital] where acute [[Physical trauma|trauma]] patients were cared for, at first mainly war wounded but later large numbers of [[landmine]] victims. Surgical equipment was donated from the [[France|French]] hospital ship ''L'Île de Lumière''.<ref>[http://www.websitesrcg.com/border/documents/Cambodian-Emergency-Refugee-Health-Care-1979-1980.pdf Grabe, Magnus, "Surgery during Khmer Refugee Assistance Efforts in Thailand," in Allegra, Nieburg and Grabe, pp. 85-88.]</ref> Initially two hospitals (A and B) were constructed with 900 beds each in 17 wards: four [[pediatric]] wards, including one intensive feeding center; two wards for [[gynecology]] and [[obstetrics]]; two surgical wards, including an admission and emergency center; one [[tuberculosis]] center; and eight general medicine wards, In addition, there was a surgical unit with two [http://www.gettyimages.com/detail/73404158/Hulton-Archive operating rooms] containing four operating tables, and a post-operative unit. There also were two hospital kitchens, a warehouse, a laboratory, and an [[x-ray]] room. Each ward housed 70-120 patients, and the maximal capacity of the entire facility was about 1,800 patients.<ref>[http://www.websitesrcg.com/border/documents/Cambodian-Emergency-Refugee-Health-Care-1979-1980.pdf Allegra, Nieburg and Grabe, p. 16.]</ref>[[File:KID Hospital.jpg|thumb|right|350px|Interior of Khao-I-Dang Hospital Ward. Photo by Chhan Touch [http://www.websitesrcg.com/border/photos/kid/ChhanTouch/811620-R1-E006.jpg].]]
The ICRC hospital began treating patients on November 27, 1979 and during its first 54 days of operation 521 surgeries were performed, 162 of these related to war injuries, including 22 amputations. Overall, 80% of operations were emergency surgery related to trauma, with the remainder performed to alleviate severe pain or bleeding. During the first two months an average of 9.5 operations per day were performed with a maximum of 16.<ref>[http://www.websitesrcg.com/border/documents/Cambodian-Emergency-Refugee-Health-Care-1979-1980.pdf Allegra, Nieburg and Grabe, pp. 87.]</ref>
By late 1980 Hospital B fell into disuse and was converted into smaller buildings for other purposes, some of which were destroyed [http://www.websitesrcg.com/border/photos/kid/ChhanTouch/Untitled-92.jpg in a fire in 1981].<ref>Levy and Susott, p. 78.</ref>
As of June 1984, the medical teams working at KID ICRC Hospital consisted of four surgeons, four anaesthetists and 13 nurses sent by nine National [[List of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies|Red Cross Societies]] ([[Belgium]], [[Finland]], [[France]], [[Iceland]], [[Japan]], [[Norway]], [[Sweden]], [[Switzerland]] and the [[United Kingdom]]). The medical co-ordinator and the administrator of the hospital were sent by the [[New Zealand]] and the [[Canada|Canadian]] Red Cross Societies respectively. Moreover, 120 Thai and Khmer medical staff assisted these teams in their work.<ref>[https://www.loc.gov/rr/frd/Military_Law/pdf/RC_Jul-Aug-1984.pdf ''International Review of the Red Cross,'' July-August 1984, pp. 241-42.]</ref>
The UN Secretary General [[Kurt Waldheim]] visited Khao-I-Dang Hospital on August 6, 1980,<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1309&dat=19800806&id=orUTAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9Y8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=4525,1186393 "UN Chief cuts short tour of flash points," ''New Straits Times,'' August 6, 1980, p. 1.]</ref> and [[Perez de Cuellar]] visited on January 27, 1985.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1828&dat=19850128&id=e0QoAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GckEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1257,7388604 "UN Chief visits camps of refugees in Thailand," ''Anchorage Daily News,'' January 28, 1985, p. A9.]</ref> Former President [[Jimmy Carter]] and First Lady [[Rosalynn Carter]] visited on June 6, 1985.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=348&dat=19850606&id=bOkuAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sjQDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5230,1051732 "Refugee Child," ''Rome News-Tribune,'' June 6, 1985, p. 4.]</ref><ref>[http://www.elpais.com/articulo/internacional/TAILANDIA/ESTADOS_UNIDOS/Carter/refugiados/elpepiint/19850607elpepiint_2/Tes/ "Carter, con los refugiados," ''El Pais'', June 7, 1985.]</ref>
== Camp closure == Khao-I-Dang's size steadily declined as its population was resettled in other countries. It eventually became a camp made up of persons who had been rejected for [[Refugee resettlement|resettlement]]; many had been rejected by more than one country. With the prospects of further resettlement diminishing, Thailand declared the camp closed at the end of December 1986. Relocations to border camps of the illegal camp residents began in March 1987. In response to international pressure, selection for resettlement of the residual population was extended again in 1988, after which Thai authorities officially decreed that all remaining refugees would be transferred to the border for [[repatriation]] to Cambodia. The residents of KID were vocal in opposition to what they felt was a [[non-refoulement|forced repatriation]] and held numerous demonstrations. By December 1989 camp population was 11,600.<ref>[http://repository.forcedmigration.org/show_metadata.jsp?pid=fmo:590 Rogge, p. 52.]</ref>
The camp finally closed on 3 March 1993 during the [[UNTAC]] operation when all remaining residents were moved to [[Site Two Refugee Camp]] to await [[repatriation]] to Cambodia.<ref>[http://www.websitesrcg.com/border/camps/Khao-I-Dang.html Khao-I-Dang - Thai / Cambodian Border Refugee Camp]</ref> At the closing ceremony, then UNHCR [[Special Envoy]] [[Sérgio Vieira de Mello]] called KID a "powerful and tragic symbol" of the Cambodian exodus and the international humanitarian response.<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/dp/0929636341 Braile, L. E., ''We shared the peeled orange: the letters of "Papa Louis" from the Thai-Cambodian Border Refugee Camps, 1981-1993.'' Saint Paul, Syren Book Co., 2005, p. 5.]</ref>
